text: We listen to the song as we pick up snapshots from an office of an early 70's music magazine: - Cigarettes are smoked indoors, everywhere. Smoke wafts over cubicles, everywhere. - Women wear mini-skirts. Really “mini” mini-skirts. - Music POSTERS and SIGNAGE line cubicle walls. Hendrix. Dylan. Simon and a Jew-fro’d Garfunkel. - A poster of a young RICHARD NIXON. Someone has drawn a MUSTACHE on Nixon’s face as well as a “SPEECH BUBBLE” which reads “I'm an asshole.” - We hone in on a SINGLE CIGARETTE. A hand places it in an ASHTRAY. The now-empty hand removes the needle from the record player (stopping the song).

Well, it’s a hell of an album, Kid. People are gonna freak. The album goes into a SLEEVE and gets placed on a table. The album’s cover bears only a simple title: Danny Collins. The cigarette gets picked back up, and the “voice” takes his place behind a desk. His other hand picks up a DICTAPHONE.
(re: recording) This cool?
Sure. He hits RECORD. A PACK OF CIGARETTES are held forward. (CONTINUED)
Smoke?

No thanks. The pack is pulled back REVEALING for the first time: OUR INTERVIEWER, GUY DELOACH (36). His style is of the day and his manner that of a hippie who thinks he knows everything about anything worth knowing. DeLoach leans back in his seat. He takes a long drag on his cigarette as he studies the YOUNG MAN opposite him.

Throughout, we see him only in FACELESS SNAPSHOTS. - Long hair, very much of the era. Open collared shirt. A hairless chest. - A single gold cross on the hairless chest. - Those few facial features we can make out are boyish, untouched by... well, anything.
Jesus H, you’re a baby. What are you, sixteen?
Twenty-one.
Jesus H. (beat, then) Well the album’s gonna be massive, Kid. Who got you there?
I’m sorry?
Your influences. Who do you dig? Who makes you hard?
(uncomfortable) Oh, well, I--
Hold on. DeLoach picks up the recorder, speaks into it. (CONTINUED )
June 30th, 1971, Guy DeLoach with Danny Collins for Chime Mag. (then) More than anything it’s your writing. You write like fucking Lennon, man.
Oh, well, that’s... thank you.
He’s clearly an influence here, no?
Yeah, I mean... I guess he’s the one who makes me the hardest? A beat. DeLoach LAUGHS, shakes his head.
Jesus H. Well, you’re going to be huge, Kid. I know the real thing when I hear it and you’re it. Danny doesn’t say anything. DeLoach raises a brow.

Kid, look at me. I’ve been a star- maker and a star-fucker for a very long time, and I’m telling you: You. Are. Going. To. Be. Huge. Richer than richer, famous as shit, more women than you know what to do with. And I’m telling you this, and I’ve got to ask: why are you sitting there, staring at me, looking like that information scares the living shit out of you? Danny leans forward, full-frame for the first time.
Because it does.
EXT. THE GREEK —- EVENING 3 The large marquee outside the famous theatre bears only four words: Danny Collins. Sold Out.
A sign on the dressing room door reads: HEADLINER. In the distance we hear a dull, thumping ROAR. THUMP. THUMP. THUMP. A distant crowd awaits their star.

A HAND fingers a CROSS. The cross dangles from a chain, half buried in a patch of gray chest hair. The cross is removed, placed on a table. The cross OPENS, like a coffin, and dumps a line of COCAINE on a table. A NOSE comes into frame, snorts some.
Preparation for show time: - GRAY HAIR STRANDS are darkened with HAIR COLORER. - A GIRDLE is strapped over an undershirt. - PLATFORM SHOES are stepped into, providing an extra five inches of height.

From behind, we TRACK our hero as he marches through the bowels of the arena in his platform shoes - his steps are wobbly, not exactly in a straight line. He passes some GIGGLING GIRLS, nods at them. He passes a few “backstage” types, including a familiar ROADIE.
Break a leg, Danny. (CONTINUED)
(from behind) Just tell me whose. The Roadie LAUGHS as Danny moves on. The CHANTING CROWD grows closer.

From behind, we watch as he pauses. One deep breath. One crack of the neck, each way. Then: He gives a THUMBS UP to someone off to the side. The curtain/door opens as he steps out onto the stage in front of 20,000 adoring fans. Needless to say, they go completely bat-shit.
We stay behind Danny as he strolls forward, takes the mic, and greets his fans.
Thanks for coming, Los Angeles. It’s good to be home. The crowd ROARS approval.

I think you might know this one. Danny turns to his BAND, NODS, and... LIGHTS BLAST ON!!! Everywhere. The crowd ERUPTS. Our CAMERA SWEEPS over the crowd revealing, in full, DANNY COLLINS for the first time since he was twenty-one. He’s still a striking man, but the years have definitely left their mark. He wears an impeccably tailored but boldly colored outfit. And those platform shoes. Equal parts Rod Stewart and Neil Diamond. There are instruments everywhere... but Danny’s not playing any of them. This is over-the-top spectacle... but not caricature. The music, the act, it’s cheesy without being cartoony, campy without being completely void of melody. It's pretty clear that the stadium isn’t the only thing that has sold out. (CONTINUED)

Danny has clearly led off with his biggest hit, akin to Sweet Caroline (equally catchy, almost as good). Sweet Caroline is a good reference actually, mainly because from the first note (and especially the chorus), the audience is SINGING ALONG in a call and response fashion (TWO VIDEO SCREENS even cue the audience to sing their part with bouncing-ball karaoke-esque prompts). The CROWD (older) eats it all up. A WOMAN sings his chorus “Hey, Baby Doll” while also wearing a “Hey, Baby Doll” T-shirt. ANOTHER WOMAN holds up a sign that reads “This Granny Loves Danny.”
During the song he mingles with women in the front row - he kisses one woman’s hand, blows a kiss to another. He makes a show out of giving one woman his SCARF. Danny takes in...

AN OLDER COUPLE, arm and arm, SING the response part of the song back at him. They’re singing way too hard. THREE OLDER WOMEN sit quietly in their front row seats, eating RED VINES and mouthing words along, lifeless. A GROUP OF YOUNG PEOPLE sings along with energy... but they’re LAUGHING. They’re not laughing with Danny.
He’s seen it all a thousand times. It no longer fazes him. He pivots with a little shimmy, keeps performing.

Danny SLUMPS in a chair, his dressing room has transformed into the site of an after-party. Danny fingers an expensive scotch (and his cross) as he does his best to stay awake. TIM, a thirty-something, comes into view through Danny’s scotch glass.
Mr. Collins, do you think I could bother you for a quick picture? (before Danny can answer ) Just real quick, my mom will die-- (CONTINUED )
A MAN in an expensive suit drinks a BOTTLE OF WATER, watches. This is FRANK GRUBMAN (60's). (CONTINUED)
(picture accomplished) Awesome, I'll tweet this to you.
Awesome. Tim, the cell-phone-photo-seeker, takes his leave. Frank shakes his head, walks over to Danny.
It was a good show, Kid.
Inspired. Frank tilts his head, takes Danny in.
Hey, Sylvia Plath? You okay?
Yeah, I’m fine. Birthday blues or some shit I guess. That’s all Frank needs to hear. He stands.
Alright everyone, sorry but my guy needs a little rest. No one really listens.
LISTEN UP YOU LEECHES, IT’S TIME

head_text.subj: TO GET THE FUCK OUT OF HERE

text: Frank, let ‘em be--
No, Danny, I can name three people in this room and that’s about three more than you can. (to room)

head_text.subj: DID I STAMMER, I SAID GET THE FUCK

text: out! The mumbling crowd begins dispersing. Once they’re gone, Danny and Frank sit in silence for a moment. Then:
Birthday’s not till tomorrow, Kid. Got a few hours till the state mandated depression has to set in. (CONTINUED)
You see the Golden Girls sitting in the front row? Eating liquorice the entire time?
Can’t choose your fans, Danny.
Three of them. Each of them older than the next. Made one pack of liquorice last the entire show. Just sat there gumming it for two hours. This hangs there. Frank tries cheering him up.
New billboard went up on Sunset for the album. You should check it out on the way home. Danny nods, staring off into space. Frank STANDS.

Alright, enough of this crap. It's your birthday tomorrow, that’s your big problem? Pregnant women in Africa, feeding half their village from their titties... those ladies have problems. Not you. Danny smiles weakly.
No, I know. You're right.

‘Course I’m right, I’m always right. So go home to your stunning half-your-age fiancé who’s throwing you the massive surprise party tomorrow that I didn’t just tell you about. Then come tell me and the sore tittied African ladies about all your problems.
Okay. He stands, goes to exit. Frank’s voice stops him.
It was a good show, Kid. Really. (CONTINUED )
Danny turns, about to say something, then thinks better of it. He simply replies:

Yeah. CUE SONG: Working Class Hero (TBD) by John Lennon. I/E. DANNY’S MERCEDES - LATER 10 It's a preposterous car for anyone... let alone a man in his sixties. Silver on the outside, leather everywhere on the inside, it’s a spaceship on wheels. Inside: Danny, exhausted, does everything he can to keep his eyes from closing as he navigates Los Angeles traffic. INT. DANNY’S MERCEDES - LATER 11 Danny eases the car up to the GATE of a MANSION. He tries using his “clicker.” It doesn’t work. He SIGHS, TOOTS the horn. In the booth of the guardhouse stands a DOORMAN, currently talking on a HOUSE PHONE. This is MARTY (40's). Marty holds up a finger ("Be with you in a second”). Danny parks, waits. After a beat, Marty hangs up and approaches. Danny SIGHS, lowers the window.
We gotta get that fixed for you, Mr. Collins. Good show tonight?
It was, thanks.
Calling it early? No after-party?
Little tired. Just looking to hit the sack so... He motions at the gate. Marty doesn’t take the hint.
What’d you open with tonight?
Same as always. (then) (MORE ) (CONTINUED )
I really gotta hit the sheets, Kid. Marty nods.

Have a good night, Mr. Collins. Marty walks toward the gate, hits a BUTTON. It opens, revealing SHANGRI-LA. Is this a home or a “Four Seasons”? Danny literally has to cross a “bridge” to get to his home.
Danny ENTERS the house.
I’m home! No response. Danny heads toward the tall staircase, looks at it, SIGHS - then turns around and gets in... An ELEVATOR, which carries him upwards.
A bed fit for a king. Fireplace. Huge flat-screen.
Babe! ?
I’m in the shower! Danny walks into...
A female figure (masked by steam) showers. The shower is roughly the size of Rhode Island. Danny walks past the shower.
Hey! Sorry I missed the show.
You've seen it before. (CONTINUED)
Danny heads into his ADJACENT WALK-IN CLOSET (filled to the brim with high-end men’s clothing in bold patterns) and begins hanging his jacket. He calls back.
What’d you do tonight?
Just busywork around here. (CONTINUED)
ll.
Always doing busywork.
It's a big house. Running it keeps a girl busy. (then) I‘1ll be out in a minute. I’m just finishing shaving.

Okay. (then, realizing) Oh, Hon? Danny turns back toward the shower. The door to the shower opens, revealing: SOPHIE (31). She’s Danny’s fiancé. She’s very young, very hot, and very naked. And she’s currently shaving her pubic hair with a disposable pink razor (shaving cream covers the region).
Jesus, Sophie.
What? He shakes his head, thrown by the sight, and turns to go. Then he stops, remembering:
Oh, yeah: the kid out front, can you do something about him? I don’t need a half hour of chitchat every time I pull into my house.
He’s just trying to impress you.
Yeah, well, he’s failing. (then) Okay, I’m gonna go write.
Okay, Baby. (then, realizing) Wait, write who?
Just... Sophie, please watch what you’re doing, you’re going to maim yourself. (MORE ) (CONTINUED )
(then) Don’t wait up, alright? He EXITS the bathroom. She calls after him.

Seriously, Baby! Who are you writing? No reply. Sophie SHRUGS, continues her grooming. INT. DANNY’S HOME STUDIO - LATER 16 It's a great space. A PIANO sits dead center. It’s obvious, however, that the room is not used often.

Covered in PLATINUM ALBUMS and framed copies of Danny’s records. The cover art on the albums tells a story - from that first SIMPLE ALBUM to the “look” he’s developed over the past decade or two (same typeface, posing, etc.). Danny ENTERS the room, looks around, and spots what he’s looking for: a BOX OF EMBOSSED STATIONARY PAPER. He carefully opens the box. Grabs a sheet. It’s blank. They're all blank. He looks until he finds... a fancy MONTBLANC-esque pen. He takes it out, looks at it, sits at the piano and takes his time perfectly setting the pen and paper into “writing position.” Danny begins playing a simple melody. A few chords. The beginning of something simple, melodic, and gentle. He pauses, puts on his glasses. Thinks for a beat, then... smiles. He grabs his pen and, just then... Catches sight of himself in the studio mirror:
An old man in a silly suit, wearing platform shoes and reading glasses, trying to write something original after what's clearly been a long hiatus from just that.
Realizing. He stops, unwilling to go further. You can see it in his eyes. What’s the point? He puts down the pen, leans back, and closes his eyes. He falls asleep sitting up.  17 13.

Danny pulls up to the house. Sophie holds leftovers in her lap; she’s dressed in something super revealing. Danny wears something that makes him look like a mid-60's pimp. You can imagine the looks they got at the restaurant.
Good birthday brunch, Baby?
(nodding) Good birthday brunch. She kisses his cheek. He smiles at her.
So how many people are inside?
Dammit! Fucking Frank! Danny SIGHS.
Honey: you can’t surprise a man my age. You want to give me a heart attack or something? She motions at her ring finger.
Not until it’s legal.
Funny.
Uch, I’m so pissed at him! Sophie reaches into her purse, pours a line of coke on the dash, bends forward and does some.
You want? Danny SIGHS.
You are trying to kill me. He accepts some, does it quickly, moves for the car door. (CONTINUED)
Sweetheart?
Yeah?
Fix your dress. Her right breast is hanging out of the low-cut dress. Danny EXITS the car.
Danny heads toward the house. We hold there a beat, then Sophie exits the car and scampers after him (attempting to fix her dress as she scampers).
They ENTER the house to a huge:
Surprise! The main living area is full of GUESTS. Danny feigns shock, looks to Frank, front and center. Frank motions to him: “act surprised.”
No way! Are you kidding me!? (to Sophie) You did this? But Sophie’s already hopped up, barely listening, rubbing her nose and sniffling. Danny covers her behavior by hugging her. The CROWD AWWWWES.

(putting on a show) Don’t you all know you don’t surprise a man my age? You could have given me a heart attack! Everyone LAUGHS. Someone CUES Danny’s MOST FAMOUS SONG (the one we saw him open the concert with).
I think I know this one! LAUGHTER. Danny couldn’t be more miserable, but he’s had decades of experience performing. And boy, can he perform. As WELL-WISHERS descend on Danny we launch:  19 14~A.
A PARTY MONTAGE (CUE SONG TBD: John Lennon’s “Whatever Gets You Through The Night”). (CONTINUED)

As Danny goes through the motions in snapshots. - He watches OLDER MEN ogle YOUNGER WOMEN frolicking in his pool. - He and Frank watch as TWO YOUNG GUESTS ransack his wine cellar. - He OPENS gifts, relishes in receiving a bottle of SCOTCH with a ribbon around it. - He DOES COKE in the bathroom, alone. - He watches two IDIOTS pour vodka/white wine in his Koi pond. - At one point, he spots Sophie chatting with Marty outside (the doorman). He watches as she hands him some CASH. - He receives the gift of a SCARF from a FAMOUS FRIEND. He places it in a pile of identical boxes (everyone has gotten him scarves). - By the time evening descends on the party, we pull away from the festivities, ending on Danny’s familiar shoes. But this time, the shoes are empty.

The party has pretty much cleared out, day has turned into night. Danny (socks, no shoes) and Frank (his Manager, we met him before) sit on Danny’s luxurious roof deck. Danny holds his recently gifted bottle of scotch (still with ribbon, now half empty). Opposite them, Sophie is passed out on a love seat. As usual, she’s hanging out everywhere.
She’s like a young Jackie 0. Danny CHUCKLES, shakes his head.
I look absurd with her.
Yes, you do. A beat. She begins to snore, drunkenly.
We have to make her sign a prenup, don’t we? (CONTINUED )
Yes, we do. Another beat.
(CONTINUED)
I’m way too old to be putting this much shit up my nose.
Yes, you are.
Jesus, don’t give me all the good stuff at once, Frank. You’re really earning that ten percent tonight, Pal.

What do you want me to say? No, Danny, you look totally normal standing next to a coked up teenager who can’t keep her nipples covered for more than five minutes. Prenup? Who needs a prenup? I mean sure, you’ve been through three wives already, but this one really seems like the real deal. Oh look, I can see her vagina again! Danny smiles.
Cute.
Thank you, I try. Frank STANDS.

Okay, so... I got you a birthday present and it cost me a fortune so do me a favor and upside down the frown for five minutes, huh? Frank smiles, bends, and picks up a wrapped GIFT. Danny starts unwrapping. Frank explains, excitedly:
I know how fanatical you are about Lennon, so I started futzing around on the internet. Ebay, Lennon memorabilia, that kind of stuff. Wrapping paper is off. Danny starts removing ribbons. (CONTINUED)
I get in touch with this one guy, a collector, say I’m looking to get you something special. Frank takes a deep breath.
Holy shit, I’ve been holding this in for three months now! (then) Danny, wait, hold on. Danny stops opening the gift.
You remember doing an interview, when you were a kid? Something called Chime Magazine? Fella named DeLoach?
(confused) Yeah. Maybe.
I don’t know what you’d said to the guy - you mentioned Lennon, doesn’t matter. Point is: Lennon read it! And he wrote you a letter! Danny lowers the box, confused.
What? Frank, what the hell are you talking about?

John Lennon wrote you a letter, Pal! In 1971. He sent it to you at the magazine, care of this DeLoach guy. DeLoach smells money - handwritten letter from John Lennon and all - so he holds onto it, never tells you. DeLoach died, he’s not the point. The point is he sold the letter to a collector. Can you believe this shit?
I’m not following this, Frank.
Open the box, just open it. (CONTINUED )
Danny does, slowly. Frank has had the letter framed and Matted, beautifully.
It’s small, handwritten. Very personalized.
A handwritten letter to you from John Lennon, written in 1971. Can you fucking believe it? Read it! Danny is still processing. He reads, out loud, slowly:

Dear Danny Collins. Yoko and I read your interview. Being rich and famous doesn't change the way you think. It doesn't corrupt your art. Only you can do that. So what do you think about that, Danny Collins? Stay true to your music. Stay true to yourself. The rest will follow. My phone number is below. Call me, we can discuss this. We can help. Love, John.
Crazy, right!? I’ve been sitting on this thing for months... As Frank continues rambling excitedly, we PUSH in...

He’s just staring at the letter. Reading it, over and over. His world has clearly just rotated on its axis. A letter from your hero, meant to be delivered to you when you were twenty-one. Warning you of all the things you wound up doing and now regret. Forty years too late. Can you imagine? CUE SONG: Imagine (TBD) written by John Lennon. Everything SLOWS as Danny looks around the deck. The imagery conflicts with the beautiful song: his fiancé, belching and half-conscious. The hangers-on passed out everywhere. His preposterously lavish mansion. Sad, horrific, irony. The song carries into...  21 22 23 24
25 19. INT. DANNY’S BEDROOM - NIGHT 21 Danny lies there holding the letter, still staring at it. It’s 5:45 AM and he hasn’t slept. He’s slowly unraveling. He gets up, whispers to Sophie:

I’ll be back late. She waves a hung-over arm at him. INT. DANNY’S MERCEDES - EARLY MORNING 22 Danny drives through Los Angeles. The Sunset Strip, home to the Roxy, the Whisky. Have you ever driven down Sunset when there’s not a soul in sight? It’s surreal. The whole time the letter sits next to Danny, on the passenger seat. Haunting him. Danny pulls the car over. EXITS.

Danny walks to the curb. Looks up. Just stares. We cut WIDE, revealing what he’s staring at: HIS GIANT BILLBOARD. Danny stands in front of it, miniscule in comparison, taking in the ridiculous picture of himself winking at/pointing at camera - the oversized portrait a symbol of every bad decision he’s ever made. And that does it... Slowly... ever so slowly: a smile creeps over his face. He cracks his neck, coming to terms with a decision, and: He gets back in the car and races off. Full speed now.
The Mercedes turns toward the gate. But then... the car keeps going.
Danny pops out from behind the “bridge.” He’s entered his own property, unseen. He scampers across the bridge.
Danny strides into the house. (CONTINUED )
I’m home! We hear frantic FOOTSTEPS in the distance. Danny smiles, marches toward the bedroom.
Sophie lies in bed, confused and a little frazzled. Danny strides past her.
I thought you were coming home late.
Change of plans. Danny heads through the bathroom into the walk-in closet. He takes out a SUITCASE, begins packing. Sophie ENTERS.
What are you doing?
Packing.
Where are we going?
Oh, I’m going away. (then) Where is he?
Who?

Whoever you were just in bed with, where is he hiding? (then) You know what, I‘’1l just ship everything. He grabs A SMALL BAG, exits the closet. Begins looking around the bathroom, grabbing toiletries.
Danny-—
Honey, I didn’t pull in, so the guy outside couldn’t call you and stall me. (MORE ) (CONTINUED )
I’m not mad, I promise, I just don’t want to open a closet and have a strange man jump out and scare the shit out of me. He’s not in the closet, is he?
(relenting) No.
Good. Danny RE-ENTERS the BEDROOM, calls out:
You can come out! I promise I’m not mad!
Jesus. (loudly) Just come out. It’s okay. A YOUNG HANDSOME MAN in TIGHTY-WHITIES comes out from under the bed. Danny smiles, continues throwing crap in his small bag.
(to the guy) You must be busywork.
Judd.
I’1l call you busywork. She’s always doing busywork. Now I understand.
(apologetic) Danny.
Sweetie, I could not be less mad. I had fun, did you have fun?
Yeah.
Good. I’m glad. You stay. Keep the house for a while. You and Busywork here. (MORE ) (CONTINUED )
Be young, have fun, I need my address book, there’s an address I need in my address book. Ah, here it is. Danny leans in toward Sophie, kisses her cheek.
I would have made you sign a prenup anyway. You’re not missing out on any big money if that makes you feel better.
I guess it does a little.
I’m glad. Danny holds his hand out toward Judd. They shake.
Busywork, take care of her.
My parents had their first dance to one of your songs, Sir.
Well that’s fucked up in all kinds of ways now, isn’t it? (then) Okay, adios Kids. He grabs his BAG and EXITS.
Danny EXITS the house, a skip in his step. He heads across his bridge as he talks on his CELL PHONE.

(into phone) Hey, have the plane ready. To New Jersey. (then) Yes, New Jersey. (then) Car, too. You know what I like. But how ‘bout a red one? (then) Yes, red. I’m changing shit up. Danny gets in his car and takes off. We can hear his LAUGHTER all the way down the street. (CONTINUED )
CUE SONG: Hold On (TBD) written by John Lennon.
Danny steps off the PRIVATE JET and heads down a set of stairs as a... RED MERCEDES (identical car, different color) pulls up next to the bottom of the stairs.
The Mercedes pulls up in front of this ordinary Hilton. The rest of the lot is littered with Toyotas and Fords.
Standing there, bored. He sees the Mercedes approach.
(re: car) Holy shit. The car pulls to a stop. Danny steps out of the car.
(re: Danny Collins) Holy shit! The kid runs forward.
Welcome to the Hilton, Danny Collins... Mr. Collins... (trying again) Welcome to the Hilton, Sir.
It's good to be at the Hilton, young man. And call me Danny. What should I call you?
Nicky Ernst.
Nicky Ernst, it’s an absolute pleasure. You have a wonderful face. Here, have a hundred dollars. He hands Nicky a HUNDRED. Nicky masks his excitement. (CONTINUED)
So. Mr... Danny... will you be staying with us, or just joining us for lunch today?

Nicky: I’m going to be staying with you, I’m going to be joining you for lunch, I’m going to be taking advantage of all the amenities the Woodcliff Lake Hilton has to offer... Nicky, I can’t help but notice that you’re drooling on my car.
Sorry. It’s just so... awesome.
You're welcome to use it whenever you want, take your girl out for a spin. You have a girl?
No.
You will if you take her out for a spin in this car.
Wait, seriously? Danny is already walking away.
(calling back) Bag goes to my room, Nicky. Car goes in a garage.

Danny walks in. It could be any hotel, in any city. A LOBBY. A lobby RESTAURANT. A lobby BAR. That’s it. A SIGN reads: “WELCOME GREATER NJ DENTAL ASSOCIATION.” There’s a DISPLAY front and center, full of “dental” swag. Danny walks to the front desk. A PRETTY YOUNG GIRL (23) works on the computer. (CONTINUED)
(not looking, bored) Welcome to the Hilton, do you have a reservation? 24A. (CONTINUED)
She SIGHS, 25.
I do not have a reservation, but I’m hoping that won’t be a deal- breaker because I am rapidly falling in love with this Hilton. looks up.
Holy shit!
I get that a lot. What is your name?
Jamie.
Jamie, I’m Danny.
I know who you are.
What about Nicky out front? Do you know who he is?
The valet guy?

Nicky Ernst. Ask him to take you for a ride in my car, you'll fall in love. (then) Look at you! Another fantastic young face. What an amazing place this Woodcliff Lake Hilton is. Why are your faces so fantastic and young?
We're all college kids I guess, off for summer or just graduated.
Ah. That must be it.
How long will you be staying with us, Mr. Collins? Danny pulls out his ADDRESS BOOK from his suit pocket. (CONTINUED)
Jamie, my GPS tells me that we’re not far from a Hillsdale, New Jersey. Now tell me: is my GPS lying to me or giving me the straight shit?
(smiling) Straight shit. You’re five minutes away.
Well, then I will be staying indefinitely. Jamie smiles, a little confused.
Okay. I'11 give you the Honeymoon Suite, it’s our nicest room... only I don’t know how to do an indefinite reservation.
Don’t need a honeymoon suite. Just a regular, everyday room. Jamie turns toward the back, yells out.
5 (calling out) lary?

If someone else with a wonderful face comes out, I don’t know if I‘ll be able to handle it. MARY SINCLAIR emerges from the BACK OFFICE. She's amazing looking, great smile... classically beautiful without trying.
Okay, I officially can’t handle it. Jamie darts over towards Mary, WHISPERS loudly.
Look who it is!
(calmly) I see. (CONTINUED)
(rapid-fire whisper) He wants to stay indefinitely. I was going to give him the Honeymoon Suite but--
(loudly) He didn’t want the Honeymoon Suite. Mary and Jamie turn toward him, synchronized.
It’s not my honeymoon and I’m not very sweet. Regular room will do just fine. Mary approaches. A beat.
And what college do you go to young lady?
Ha.
Ha.
You’re staying indefinitely? Here?
Huge fan of this Hilton. (then) Are you married, Mary?
I’m sorry?
Are you currently betrothed?
No.
Good. Dinner?
You’re asking me to dinner? (CONTINUED)
I think so. Jamie, I asked her to dinner, didn’t I?
(excited) You did.
I’m sorry, are you on drugs?
Currently or in general?
Currently.
No. (then) Dinner?
I’m sorry, I’m going to have to decline.
Not a fan of mine?
Currently or in general?
In general.
No.
God, we have a great patter, don’t we!? Jamie, can you follow any of this?
(giggling, excited) No! Mary smiles, shakes her head.
I’‘1l check you in.
While you check me in, I’1l check you out. (CONTINUED)
Oh my God. Mary goes back to the computer. Despite herself: she can’t help but smile, just a little.
It could be any hotel room in the world. A bed, a small desk, a love seat. That’s it. Danny takes it in, thinks.
Danny oversees as FOUR LARGE MEN try to figure out how to move a BABY GRAND PIANO through the door to his room.
Everything has been moved to make room for the massive piano, which dwarfs everything else.
Taking it in. He may as well be taking in the Sistine Chapel. He digs into his bag, and pulls out the framed LENNON LETTER. Sets it up on his nightstand. He takes in his strange new home and smiles:
Perfect.
PATRONS talk, whisper, point at...

head_text.subj: THE OTHER SIDE OF THE ROOM

text: Where Danny sits at the bar. He’s wearing a customary over-the-top suit and is drinking scotch. He’s writing furiously. It’s important to note that he’s finally able to write using hotel stationary and an ordinary hotel pen, aS opposed to his Montblanc and embossed stationary. ON THE PAD: the beginnings of a lyric. Stuff about the seasons - “spring” and “fall.” Just a start.
Danny? Danny turns. Frank stands there. (CONTINUED)
Frank! Danny stands, envelopes Frank in a surprising BEAR HUG.
Sit, sit. Thanks for coming.
Got on the first flight out.
Thanks. Have you been here before?
The bar at the Woodcliff Lake, New Jersey Hilton? (then, obviously) No. Frank sits. He’s obviously concerned.
I spoke to Sophie. She said you--
I did. (then, calling out) Barkeep? An ice water for this handsome young man, por favor? Danny turns toward Frank, serious.
Frank, I’ve decided to make some big changes in my life. Some of them may come as a bit of a shock, some of them may even affect you financially. Frank puts his hand on Danny’s knee.
I’m here as your friend, Danny. Not as your manager.
Actually, I need you to be here as my manager for a moment. (then) I want you to cancel the rest of my tour.
I’m sorry? (CONTINUED )

Don’t be sorry, I’m not sorry. I’m done, Frank. (then) Oh, I’1l also need you to call Bill, tell him to sell all my stock, all the houses. I want no debt, no risk. So help me God I will never be forced to sing those songs again. Oh, wait, tell Bill not to sell the LA house yet. I’m going to let Sophie and the kid she was cheating on me with stay there--
Danny, stop! You’re spiraling. Are you on something? What did you take?
Nothing, I promise. Actually, I’m done with that shit too. No more drinking, no more drugs--
You’re drinking right now, Danny.
True. Okay, forget what I said about the drinking. I’m not running for Pope, right?
This is because of Sophie?
Sophie? No! Jesus, Frank, give me a little credit. Danny puts down his drink. Changes tone.
What if I had gotten the letter when I was supposed to, Frank? He was my hero. I would have called him. (then) Maybe my life would have turned out different.
You’re too hard on yourself, Kid. Always have been. (CONTINUED)

I haven’t written a song in thirty years, Frank. I’m a fucking joke. I’m a court jester with a microphone. (then) I was the real thing once, Frank. One album. My songs didn’t sell so they handed me theirs and I sang them. I gave up, Frank. Frank leans forward, concerned. Gently:
You’re having a breakdown, Danny.

Hate to tell you, Buddy, but I’ve been breaking down for forty years. I’m broken. Ain’t nothing left to break. (beat, then) I’m sixty-four, Frank. I’ve been abusing my body for the better parts of four decades. If I’m gonna find any kind of redemption, I can’t waste anymore time. A beat, then:
Why New Jersey?
One shock at a time, Frank. Frank nods, sips his water.
A sixty-something man starts canceling tours, people start wondering. I’m talking to you as your manager, Danny.
Actually, I need you to be my friend again now. Frank nods, sits there for a beat, then:
I’ll cancel the tour. Danny nods back, clinks his scotch against Frank’s water. They turn back toward the bar in unison. (CONTINUED)
After a beat, from behind, Frank puts his hand on Danny’s shoulder. There’s nothing left to say.
Danny walks through the lobby, a spring in his step. His outfit/suit is typically bold. He stops at the front desk. Jamie and Mary are there.
Jamie, have you talked to Nicky Ernst about taking that ride yet?
Not yet, Mr. Collins. He turns to Mary.
Dinner at seven? I’1ll meet you... He points five feet away.
There?
Still gonna have to pass.
Mary, you keep passing, I'll keep making passes, we’ll see who gives up first, sound good?
Have a nice day, Mr. Collins.
Big day for me. Meeting someone for the first time. How do I look?
Honestly?
If this relationship is going to go the distance, Mary, I think we should always be honest with one another.
You look ridiculous. (CONTINUED)
Nah, I look sharp. See you at seven.
No you won't.
And round and round we go. (turning) Jamie, don’t forget about Nicky Ernst. Wonderful young man.
Danny steps outside, Nicky waits with his car.
Nicky my boy!
She’s ready for you, Sir.
The girl at the front desk, she won't stop talking about you, Nicky. You should ask her out.
(stunned) Jamie?
That’s the one. Don’t go after Mary, Mary's mine. Danny gets in the car, rips out of the parking lot.

A very modest HOUSE, in a very modest NEIGHBORHOOD. This is “real world” central. TOYS are scattered around the lawn. It could not be more ordinary. And up to this house pulls a gleaming, red Mercedes. Driven by Danny Collins. National superstar. Wearing, what can best be described, as a zoot suit. As he strides across the lawn, stepping over a tricycle, a SUBURBAN DAD raking leaves does a double take.  38 EXT. FRONT DOOR —- CONTINUOUS Danny RINGS the bell. No sound. He rings again. Nothing. He RAPS on it. He holds a BROWN BAG. Footsteps from inside. Danny braces himself. The OPENS, revealing: (CONTINUED)
Nobody.
Hello. Danny looks downward at: A LITTLE GIRL (7). This is HOPE, Danny’s granddaughter. Needless to say, Hope is pretty fucking cute.
Hello.
Hope, you are not to open that door for strangers!
He’s not a stranger. We saw him on TV. Mom, come here, it’s the guy we saw on TV. Mom, Mom--

What? Hope’s mother arrives. This is SAMANTHA (30's). Samantha is pretty and pregnant. She’s a study in contrasts: tough but emotional, sexy but a little tomboyish, and - at the moment - calm but completely thrown by the sight of Danny Collins on her front doorstep.
Whoa.
Told you. I told you. You didn’t listen but I tried to tell you.
Hi, I’m Danny.
We know who you are.
(imitating) Yeah! We know who you are!
(to Hope) Settle, Baby. Inside voices, okay? Samantha and Hope look back up at Danny.
I don’t really know who you are. (CONTINUED )
Danny bends down, takes in Hope for the first time. He touches her face, gentle. Up above them, Samantha doesn’t move, unsure what to do. Danny stands back up, offers forth his BROWN BAG.
I was unsure of what was appropriate to bring...
He’s at work.
So I brought bagels.
Wow. Okay. This is weird. I guess... come in? Danny follows them into the house.
We see FAMILY PICTURES on the fridge. Child drawings. A dirty pan in the sink. There are no granite tops here. It's warm, but tight. Danny, Sam, and Hope sit in the small kitchen.
How did you--
I hired someone to track him down years ago. Never got up the nerve until now. Danny puts the bagels on the table.
I want a bagel, can I have a bagel Mommy ! ? As Samantha starts cream-cheesing a bagel for Hope, she looks at Danny.
Wow. I mean... wow on so many levels.
Too much cream cheese Mommy-- (CONTINUED)
Samantha realizes what she’s doing. 36A. (CONTINUED)
Sorry, Baby.
How far along are you?
Six months.
Boy or girl, do you know?
Boy.
A boy. Wow.
On so many levels. (beat, then) I have to call him.
Of course. She walks over to the counter, keeping an eye on Danny.
So... Hope, what grade are you in?
I just finished the first grade. My teacher is named Mrs. Williams. Her aunt died last week so we had a substitute. He had a mustache. Why are you on TV?
Because I’m a singer.
Are you a good singer?
No, not really.
I didn’t think so.
Hope!
(smiling) Why didn’t you think so? (CONTINUED )

Because when you were on the TV, Daddy said “Shut it off, Samantha,” and Mommy turned it off really fast, and then Mommy said, “Tom?” and Daddy said, “No” and that was that. Samantha starts to say something, but then starts talking into the phone (he’s gotten on the line). As she talks, she steps out of the room.

Hey, so... your fa... Danny Collins just showed up at the house. (long beat) Uh-huh. I know. Having bagels in the kitchen with Hope. (beat) What was I supposed... (beat) Yes. Okay. She hangs up, returns into the kitchen, puts on a big fake smile, and announces:
He’s coming home.
Yay! Danny looks at Samantha. She SHRUGS.
Hope is watching television, completely absorbed. Danny and Samantha sit awkwardly on the couch behind her, watching her watch the television.
I have so many questions.
Ask away.
I can’t think of any of them now. Hope SCREAMS at the TV.
Hope? Calm, okay? (CONTINUED)
Danny looks at Hope... currently running around in small circles, dancing. It’s partially adorable, partially manic.
She seems... energetic.
Severely hyperactive. Learning issues, behavioral stuff, we do the best we can but it’s a battle-- why are you here? The question’s delivery catches Danny by surprise.
I’m making some changes.
It’s a little late for that, isn’t it?
Maybe. I hope not. Samantha leans back, thinks for a moment. Then:

My husband is the best man I’ve ever met. Solid. Kind. Funny. We've had one fight. Twelve years, one serious fight. Two years ago, I got backstage passes to one of your shows, thought it was time he should... at least meet you. (then) He disagreed. He disagreed strongly.
So this isn’t going to be pretty?
No. I wouldn't imagine it will be.
Well, if you could help grease the wheels at all--
Mr. Collins, my parents are dead. His mom is too. I'd like my daughter to know her one remaining grandparent, I would. (MORE ) (CONTINUED )

I’d like my husband to know his father. And I’1l admit to being a little star-struck by you. But in a minute, my husband is going to walk through that door. And when he does, I’m confident that this will be the last time I ever see you. And despite your celebrity, and despite what I want for my family, I will not try and stop that. You did this to yourself. Shame on you. Danny NODS, understanding.
That was good.
(emotional) I’ve been practicing it in my head since you gave me the bagels. Danny smiles.
He married well.

Yeah, I’m pretty great. You see? You really missed out. And just then: the FRONT DOOR opens. There stands TOM (40). Handsome. He wears boots, work clothes, clearly fresh off a construction job. He could not be dressed less like the man currently sitting on his couch.
Daddy! Daddy! Tom’s eyes remain fixed on Danny as he hugs Hope (who is becoming overwhelmed by all the excitement).
(hyper ) Look who it is! It’s the man from TV! It’s the man from the TV that we saw singing, and Mommy said “whoa” and he brought bagels--
Hope, easy.
He brought bagels and Mommy called you and now you’re home early and-- (CONTINUED )
(calmly) Hope? She looks up at him. Tom begins an adorable father- daughter calming ritual; the whole time never breaking his “if looks could kill” stare at Danny.
Your favorite flower is a--
Rose!

To smell it you breathe through your... She takes a deep breath through her nose. It’s all a bit surreal: watching a man settle his daughter with a nursery rhyme while staring daggers at his long-lost father.
(rhyming/glaring) Keep it in, long as you can go, then let it out, in one... big... blow. Hope lets out her breath, a bit settled.
(to Samantha) Hi Honey.
Hi Baby.
(to Danny) Could I speak to you outside for a second?
Of course. Danny stands, offers his hand to Samantha.
If I have, then I am truly very sorry to have missed out on you.
(formal) Thank you for the bagels. (CONTINUED)
(smiling) Okay. Tom guides his daughter towards Danny.
Hope, say goodbye to Mr. Collins.
Goodbye to Mr. Collins.
Mr. Collins, say goodbye to Hope. Danny kneels down, takes a knowing last look at his granddaughter.

(sad smile) Goodbye to Hope. He stands, follows Tom out the door. 4l EXT. TOM AND SAMANTHA'S HOUSE - CONTINUOUS 4l Tom closes the door behind them. They stare at each other for a long beat. A really long beat. Finally:
You’re so tall.
(calmly) I’m sorry. What exactly do you want?
I just--
Are you sick? Is that why you’re here? Are you dying?
No. I’m not sick. Danny takes a deep breath, contemplating. Then:
You have every right to be angry-- (CONTINUED)
4l
I’m not angry, I’m really not. I’m a little confused, and strangely not interested. So if you have anything to ask me, go ahead, because this will be the last time we see each other. Danny NODS.
What do you do for a liv--
I work construction. Local residential. Not my dream job but it’s steady and Princeton wasn’t exactly in the cards. What else?
Your mom--—

Died of cancer ten years ago. Never married, never spoke about you except to say it was a wild thing she did when she was twenty- three and got drunk backstage after a concert. I use her last name. Anything else?
You're clearly very angry.
I’m not angry, I don’t care enough to be angry. I’m thinking about what I’m going to tell my daughter about you, and I’m thinking that I have to be back at work in twenty minutes. Are we done?
I’ve sent you checks.
Ripped them up. Okay? Nice to meet you, have a good life. Tom heads back inside. One last question stops him.
Are you happy?
Am I happy? (CONTINUED )
Do you have a happy life? Tom turns around. He finally slows down a little.

I hate my boss. Mets break my heart every year. But I have the best wife in the history of wives. An amazing little girl. I wish I could do more for her. I'd do anything for that. But yes. If it makes you sleep better, I’m happy. Oh, and fuck you, you selfish prick. I am angry. Tom ENTERS the house, slams the door behind him. Danny stands there for a moment, then trudges back to his car. CUE SONG: Beautiful Boy (TBD) written by John Lennon.
Danny drives the car up toward the valet. Nicky waits:
You were right! Jamie talked to me today. She’s never talked to me before!
That's good, Kid. That’s real good. He trudges away, inside the hotel.
Danny walks in, passing Jamie at the counter.
Hey, Mr. Collins!
Jamie, how ya doing? Jamie is about to respond, but Danny doesn’t wait for a reply. Jamie watches him go, surprised.
Danny rests his head on the hotel bar, cheek to bar. He’s been here a while. His eyes are closed. (CONTINUED )
Mary steps into frame.
Mr. Collins, how we doing tonight? Danny doesn’t move, doesn’t open his eyes.
Peachy, thanks for asking.
That’s good. Real glad to hear that. Neither of them moves. Danny just lies there. Mary just stands there. After a beat:
Mr. Collins?
(head still down) Yes?

Wonder if you could help me with something? When a famous musician starts getting fall-down drunk at a hotel bar, and you’re the Manager of that hotel, is there a protocol on how to handle the situation? We’ve had a shortage of famous fall-down drunk musicians here lately and I'ma bit out of my depth. Danny finally opens his eyes, looks up.
I had a bad day.
Okay. He points at his glass.
That's just water.
Yes, but that’s because the ice melted. Danny nods. He suddenly looks very vulnerable. (CONTINUED)
Please don’t be mean to me. I really did have a bad day. She nods, SIGHS.
Yeah, well, I had a bad day, too. She sits down next to Danny, three seats away. Danny looks over at her. She’s staring into space.
Can I buy you a drink? Mary looks at Danny, blankly. Danny presses on.
Wine spritzer? Bay Breeze? Something froz-- Mary WHISTLES.
Josh? Tequila, rocks, something afiejo. Splash of soda.
Right away, Boss. Danny looks at Mary, surprised.
You’re not the only rock star in this hotel.
Apparently not. Danny takes in Mary. She’s back looking off into space. These are two very lost souls.
Why’d you have a bad day?

Oh, because I work with a bunch of well-meaning but remarkably dim twenty-somethings who are just passing time until they go back to school. And one of them screwed up the computer system and it took me half the day to reprogram every reservation manually. Her drink is delivered, she takes a sip. (CONTINUED )
You? Danny takes a sip, bracing himself. Then:
I tracked down my grown son who I’d never met before. Met him, his wife, my granddaughter. Then he told me, quite emphatically, to fuck off and die. She processes this, then:
EVERY reservation, each one had to be reprogrammed manually. I hope I made that clear. Danny LAUGHS. Mary leans forward, serious.
Can I ask you a question?
Not if it’s about why I’ve never met my son until today.
Shit. That was my question. They sit there for a long beat, then, turn back to the bar, and sip their drinks in silence.
They’re still just sitting there, sipping. Finally:
We've lost our patter. Mary NODS, sips. After a long beat...
I saw you in concert once. About five years ago.
Yeah?
My husb-- (correcting) My ex was a fan. He loved it. (CONTINUED)
And you?
I appreciated your... zeal.
(“ouch”) Shit.
“Zeal’s” not awful.
“Zeal's” not great. A beat. Then Danny LAUGHS.

“Zeal’s not awful, zeal’s not great.” I’m telling you, Mary, this is some kind of patter we have! We should take this on the road, we could be the new Nichols and May. She shrugs, takes a sip. A long beat of silence, then:
May and Nichols. Danny looks up.
I'd want top billing. Danny smiles.
We pick them up, many minutes (and many drinks) later. Danny now stands near Mary, who sits facing him (back to bar).
--. and then he writes, “What do you think about that, Danny Collins?”
(repeating, laughing) John Lennon writes, “What do you think about that, Danny Collins!?” (CONTINUED )

Yes. (as if answering) I don’t know, John. I think you should have sent the letter to my house so I could have avoided living a bullshit life for the past forty years, that’s what I think. Mary explodes in laughter.
As Mary reveals herself a little in front of a fireplace inside the bar:
She’s eighteen now. Rick and I split last year. Yeah, most parents try and wait till the kids leave for college but we tried to do it at the time when it would screw her up most.
Did it work?
Oh, yeah. She’s a complete mess. Hates both of us. But guess what?
What? Mary leans in, whispers conspiratorially:
She hates him more.
Perfect! Mary suddenly becomes emotional and vulnerable:
Okay I don’t like joking about this anymore. I’m a good mother, I swear.
(whoa) No, I know. (CONTINUED )
I was just trying to be funny.
I know!

(completely gone) We did split up at the worst time possible but I don’t think she hates me. Oh, maybe she does. I don’t want any more tequila! She’s crying now, but also laughing. It’s incredibly appealing.
A quieter moment:
I went on Match.com last week.
How was that?

I started filling out a profile. Divorced. Grown daughter. Hotel Manager. I started crying. I started crying from my own profile. (then) Rick will find some fun young thing. My daughter will go off to college next year. (then) I’m going to be alone for the rest of my life.
Not if you marry me.
Yes, well, I’1l keep that in my hip pocket, thank you.
Hey, I’m great at being married. Done it three times. (then) My second wife was actually one of the stars of Gilligan's Island. Mary looks up. (CONTINUED)
Ginger? He shakes his head “no.” Suddenly, Mary gets it.
Mary Ann! He smiles.
Holy shit! You were married to Mary Ann!? That’s insane!
Danny sits at the piano, looks at his hotel stationary pad. Mary, meanwhile, is looking at the LETTER FROM LENNON.
You better have something to play me. Because if this was just a lame attempt to get me to your room-—
I have something to play you.
(re: letter) This is truly unreal. She shakes her head, puts the letter down. Danny settles. He’s nervous.
Okay, so, I haven’t written anything in a long time and--
Why?
Nothing to write about, I guess. And I wasn’t a great pianist to begin with so--
Enough stalling, Collins. Play it. Danny cracks his neck, then: (CONTINUED)
He starts playing. He’s playing the same MELODY he started back in the fancy studio of his mansion, before he'd received Lennon’s letter. But now it has words. (CONTINUED)
Danny starts to sing... the music is simple, the melody and lyrics wrenching.
It’s spring in my mind/But the autumn leaves they fall/As I’m walking by/I collect them all... Danny stops, looks up.
Keep going, keep going!
That’s as far as I got. Mary looks confused.
Honestly, this kind of was just a lame attempt to get you to my room.
Jesus Christ. Mary shakes her head, stands.
Come on! Stay! I’m an old man with ten scotches in him. The odds of anything risqué happening here are very, very slim.
(with a smile) Goodnight, Danny.
(giving up) Goodnight, Mary. She stops at the door.
The song’s beautiful, Danny. A little short, but it’s going to be beautiful.
Thank you. She EXITS the room, stops in the HALLWAY. (CONTINUED)
And hey, about what we talked about? You shouldn’t give up. 52A. (CONTINUED)
I agree. (then, immediately) Mary, will you have dinner with me tomorrow?
Not that. Your son. Danny smiles.
I know.
Okay. (then) But don’t give up on dinner either.
(immediately) Mary, will you have dinner with-- But the door closes before he can finish.
Completely smitten... and maybe even a little inspired. 49

HOTEL GUESTS (and a lot of DENTISTS) are crammed around the GLASS DOOR, looking inside... INT. WOODCLIFF LAKE HILTON BUSINESS CENTER —- CONTINUOUS Where national icon Danny Collins sits at a COMPUTER wearing only a HOTEL ROBE and SLIPPERS. He has PAPERS scattered around him, everywhere. - He takes notes. - He sends faxes. - He makes calls. - In between he behaves as if he’s Eloise at the Plaza: LINE COOK brings in a plate from the BREAKFAST BUFFET. NEWSPAPER is delivered. COFFEE refills are served. A TAILOR measures him for a new suit jacket. 50 51
(CONTINUED)
- We hear and see bits and pieces of everything: Danny explaining who he is over the phone. Danny giving a credit card number. Danny asking how quickly whatever he’s planning can happen.
Spectators watch. Jamie approaches Nicky from behind (he doesn’t see her).
What’s he doing?

He’s bitch slappin’ the business center is what he’s-- (then, seeing her) Oh, hey. Mary pushes through the spectators to see what’s going on. She sees Danny pacing around inside, a man possessed. She smiles, doesn’t interrupt. EXT. TOM AND SAMANTHA’S HOUSE - NEXT DAY 52 A quiet morning in the neighborhood. THE SAME SUBURBAN DAD now waters his lawn next door. DANNY'S GIANT TOUR BUS pulls up to the curb, catching the dad’s attention. It dwarfs the entire street, takes out branches at it comes to a stop. And out steps Danny Collins, wearing one of his finest get-ups. Danny walks towards his son’s front door. As he passes, he NODS to the neighbor.
Mornin’.
(stunned) Hi. Danny RINGS the bell (he forgot it doesn’t work), then knocks per usual. The door opens. It’s Samantha:
(re: Danny) Oh fuck me. (CONTINUED)
Language, Dear. 54A. (CONTINUED)
Hope runs to the door, sees Danny.
WE DON’T WANT YOUR MUSIC! Danny bends down, confused.
You don’t want my music? Samantha explains, pointedly:
Tom explained to Hope the other day how you’re a musician and how some musicians go door to door to sell their music.
Ohhh. Okay.

(still explaining) But we weren’t interested in buying any music. Much the same way some people aren’t interested in buying Girl Scout cookies. Doesn't mean we’re rude, just that we weren’t interested in buying any music.
No, I get it. Possibly more complicated an explanation than required for a seven year old, but okay. Hope spots the bus.
Mommy look, Mommy look, do you see this?
(to Danny) Just out running some errands? Hope runs for it.
Hope!
(calling out) Jimmy. (CONTINUED)
A DRIVER (Jimmy) gets out. He opens a door for Hope, lets her in.
She’s fine, he’s got her. Tom arrives at the door, sees Danny.
(re: Danny’s presence) Are you fucking kidding me?
Oh good, we’re all here.
You have a hell of a nerve--
Have you heard of the New Compass School, in Manhattan? Tom stops.
What?
It's one of the most progressive private schools in the country. It uses... hold on: He pulls a piece of paper out of his pocket, reads:
“A multimodal approach toward treating children with learning issues, particularly ADHD.” (then) I pulled some strings. You have an interview in two hours. Hope pops out of the bus.
It has a SHOWER!!! And she’s back inside. Tom turns back toward Danny.
Do you really think that we haven't looked into every school-- (CONTINUED)
Well you haven’t looked into this one.
And how exactly do you know that? 56A. (CONTINUED)
(quietly) Because you can’t afford it. Tom steps forward, he’s had enough.
You know what--
(sharply) Tom. Tom goes quiet, then:
Stephen, would you mind your fucking business please. Behind them, their nosy LANDSCAPING NEIGHBOR slips out of frame. Samantha motions towards Danny to continue. Danny takes the opportunity.
People wait two years to get an interview. You have one in two hours. Samantha looks at Tom. Tom says nothing.

Just give me one day to do something good for you. Then I’m gone forever. You'll still go to heaven ‘cause you’re so damn tolerant, and I’1l still go to hell because you can’t buy redemption. Everyone wins. Tom looks at Samantha. She clearly wants this. He shakes his head. There’s no stopping this train.
If you guys want to bring any friends, there’s room. INT. TOUR BUS —- LATER A53 The THREE ADULTS awkwardly sit in the enormous bus as Hope runs around like a maniac.  53 57A.
Like many top private schools in Manhattan, it’s a mansion converted into a school. It looks like a place superheroes in an X-Men prequel should attend. The TOUR BUS sits outside.  54 58.
The family stands in the middle of the school, staring. It's awe-inspiring.
This is a school?
I’m not sure, Baby. A MAN (40's) ENTERS in workout clothes. This is the HEADMASTER, RYAN KURTZ. He’s reading from a CLIPBOARD.
Sorry to keep you waiting. And sorry I’m dressed like Jack LaLanne, I’m elastic-only on the weekends. I’m Dr. Kurtz, the headmaster here--
Tom Donn--
(re: Danny) Holy cow, you really are Danny Collins! Kurtz beelines for Danny. Tom continues introducing himself, even though Kurtz is no longer listening.
(to no one) --Tom Donnelly, my wife, Samantha, our daughter, Hope, my balls are in my wife’s purse, if you’re lucky you can meet them later. Samantha smiles, smacks him. Danny shakes Kurtz’s hand.
Wow, seeing you in person is way different than talking to you on the phone.
Good to meet you, Doc. Kurtz turns to Tom.
And you must be Hope. (CONTINUED)
(not that amused) Tom. Kurtz feigns confusion, turns toward Samantha.
Then... you must be Hope.
Samantha.
Then who’s Hope? Hope, of course, finds this routine hysterical.
I’m Hope! I’m Hope! Over here, that’s me, I’m Hope--
Easy, Baby. Kurtz smiles.
Let me show you guys around. We're only half speed during our summer camp programs but you can still get a sense of the place. They follow him off. Danny holds still, unsure what to do.
C'mon, you. You started all this. Danny hesitates, looks toward Tom. Tom, exasperated, throws up his hands in defeat.
Kurtz leads them through the unbelievable facilities... technology-filled classrooms and a college level gymnasium catch the eye. Hope runs ahead, excited.
Hope!

Grandpa! Danny looks up and drops the letter to the ground, as coke goes flying.
Tom, Samantha, and Hope stand there.
(confused) Grandpa? Samantha quickly pulls Hope back. Tom looks on, shocked. (CONTINUED)
Nice. (pointedly) Real nice, Grandpa.
I’m sorry, I didn’t--
Don’t. Don’t even bother. He turns away, then turns back, furious. He moves at Danny quickly. Grabs him. He could hit him, but he catches himself. He looks at Danny, a beaten man.
Jesus. He turns to go. Danny calls out:

Yes, keep judging me, Tom, you're great at that. When you finish - you know, being so perfect and honorable - maybe you should talk to your wife about what you did in “Delaware.” As soon as he says it he regrets it. Tom freezes. Samantha (pushing Hope out the door) stops, confused.
Huh? Tom glares at Danny. Samantha looks at Tom, it’s too weird not to comment on.
What’s he talking about? Tom turns to her. She looks at him, expectant. He knows it’s over.
We’ll talk at home, okay? He leads his family out the door, but not before turning back towards Danny.
If you ever come near my family again... He trails off. The message is clear. Nothing left to say. And with that... (CONTINUED)
He EXITS.
Completely undone. He bends down, picks up the LENNON LETTER off of the ground.
It's cracked, smattered with cocaine. Symbolic.
Who turns towards Sophie and Judd.
Let’s get the fuck out of here. CUE SONG: Cold Turkey (TBD) written by John Lennon. INT. DANNY’S HOTEL ROOM - NEXT MORNING 88 We hear a KEY go into a door. The door opens.

Walking through the small hotel room: The room is trashed. Bottles and cans everywhere. The LENNON LETTER lies on the floor, cracked. There’s an overturned ROOM SERVICE TABLE in the center of the room. And on the bed, Danny is sprawled out, unconscious. His shirt half unbuttoned. A BOTTLE OF BOOZE on his chest.
Revealing Mary, the source of our POV. Taking in the train wreck. Just then... SOPHIE stumbles out of the bathroom.
(wasted) Who are you?
I... um... I work for the hotel.
Oh, good. We need more towels, can you do that? And some beer. (CONTINUED)
Yes. More towels. And some beer. The conversation causes Danny to STIR. He opens his eyes, sees...
Mary. Mary turns, walks out of the room.
Mary heads for the elevator. Half stumbling, half dressed, Danny runs after her.
Mary! Mary, wait! Mary turns.
She’s not... it’s not what it looks like.
What the hell happened last night, Danny? Danny looks down.
It just wasn’t right. It wasn’t the right time.
What are you talking about!? You’ve been working so hard. Your whole family was there--
I couldn’t. I just... lost my nerve. She takes him in. He’s barely making eye contact.
Yeah, well, you lost your dinner, too.
Mary-- The elevator door opens. (CONTINUED)

You should have played the song, Danny. You should have at least played the one fucking song. Mary GETS IN THE ELEVATOR, leaving Danny alone in the hallway.  90 91 92 92. INT. DANNY’S HOTEL ROOM - CONTINUOUS 90 Danny RE-ENTERS his room. He picks up the LENNON LETTER from the floor, looks at it.
(to letter) Fuck you, John.
Danny rolls his SUITCASE into the elevator. He's leaving. As the elevator descends, it plays THE MUZAK of Danny's most famous song. Danny NODS, knowingly. One last final body blow before he goes.
Danny rolls his SUITCASE through the lobby. Jamie works behind the front desk. Danny sees her.
You take care of yourself, Jamie.
You too, Mr. Collins.
And be good to Nicky. He’s a good boy. Wonderful face.
Yours isn’t so bad either, Mr. Collins.

Well look at that: now we're getting patter. Danny looks behind Jamie, toward the OFFICE that hides beyond the front desk. Jamie shakes her head “no.” Mary doesn’t want to see him. Danny nods, steps up to the desk, and yells out:
FOR THE RECORD: MARY ANN’S REAL

Nicky pulls up the Mercedes, loads in the SUITCASE.
Nicky, it’s been a pleasure.
The pleasure has definitely been mine, Danny. Danny reaches into his pocket to TIP Nicky. But he’s got no cash.
Shit. (then) You know what? Danny goes to his trunk, removes the suitcase, and WHISTLES for a cab (in line at the nearby stand). He hands NICKY the KEYS to the Mercedes.
You’re kidding me. Danny smiles.
The second you stop appreciating it, you give it to someone else. Deal?
Deal.
Good. Now get the hell out of here. Nicky doesn’t know what to do with himself. He BEAR HUGS Danny, gets in the car, and ZOOMS off.
Wait! (CONTINUED)
93 Mary runs out, catches up to him. They stand there.

I don’t want the last thing I ever said to you to be mean. But I don’t want to say anything nice. So... (then) Mr. Collins: on behalf of the Woodcliff Lake Hilton, we hope you enjoyed your stay and hope you will choose to make Hilton home, wherever you travels take you. They stand there in awkward silence.
I’m grabbing a cab.
I see that.
I gave Nicky my Mercedes.
You're fucking crazy.
It's been said, yes. Danny turns to her. He smiles.
I called Frank this morning. I’m going back on tour.
Good. Good, right?
I need the money. I have a family now. They hate my guts, but I’m told that’s just what families do.
I’ve taught you well.
I’m gonna play my new songs. At least some of them. We’1ll see what happens. (CONTINUED)
I know what will happen.
They’1l throw tomatoes?
Onions.
Better. Danny loads his suitcase into the TAXI.
Tour comes to The Garden in a few months. Maybe I could take you to dinner after the show?
(with a smile) You’re relentless. Danny gets in the taxi, lowers the window.
I left you something in the room.
You probably left me a big mess is what you left me.
Hey, you know us rock stars. Danny takes her in one last time, smiles.
Another life, huh?
You never know. Danny smiles, winks, and taps the window. He came to the Woodcliff Lake Hilton in a red Mercedes. He leaves in a yellow taxi.  94 95

INT. DANNY’S HOTEL ROOM - LATER 94 Mary ENTERS the room with TWO CLEANING LADIES. But the room... Is immaculate. Danny has cleaned it himself. On the bed, sits the LENNON LETTER. Next to it, a SECOND NOTE, from Danny: It reads: “What do you think about that, Mary Sinclair?”
Well I’1l be damned. He made a clean exit. She chuckles to herself, stands, and kicks Busywork (sprawled on the floor).
Be out of the room by noon. And with that, Mary Sinclair EXITS. CUE SONG: Jealous Guy (TBD) written by John Lennon.
Danny sits in his seat, waiting for liftoff. He talks on his cell.
Yeah, I’1l meet you guys in Pittsburgh. Frank’s setting up the other dates. Okay, talk soon. A STEWARDESS approaches.
We're ready for takeoff, Mr. Collins. Say goodbye to New Jersey. He looks out his window, speaks to himself.
Goodbye to New Jersey.  96 96A.

A pair of feet makes the familiar trek past Tom’s front yard. A finger rings the familiar doorbell. Rings again. Still broken. The hand knocks. The door opens. It’s Tom. Standing opposite him is... Frank.
Oh Jesus. What now? Did he send you to check on me?
The hotel didn’t know what to do with the damn piano. I thought you might want it. (CONTINUED)
Frank motions to a MOVING TRUCK out front manned by FOUR LARGE MEN. Tom shakes his head.
I don’t want his piano.

Well, it took six hours to move it out of the Hilton and I don’t know anyone else in New Jersey, so tough shit. (then) It's a thirty thousand dollar instrument, Tom. Sell it for all I care. A beat, then Tom nods, exhausted. Frank motions at the movers, they start opening the truck.
Your health?
(shrug) Find out in a few days. Frank nods, takes a sip from his ubiquitous water bottle.

When I was in my thirties, I started drinking. Heavily. Don’t remember how it started. Everyone was always drinking before his shows. After his shows. Long line of drunks in my family, all the usual bullshit excuses. Out of nowhere, Frank yells at the movers behind him:
Careful, gentlemen, that’s a Steinway. It’s worth more than you are. He turns back to Tom, SHRUGS, continues.

We were on tour in the Bay Area and I fell asleep at the wheel. Almost killed myself, a few others. Got arrested. Your fa-- (then) Danny bailed me out. Five in the morning he showed up at the San Jose police station high as a fucking kite. (MORE ) (CONTINUED )

Drives me six hours straight to this Hollywood rehab joint... probably drove us there drunker than I'd been the night before, the dumb shit. Paid for the whole thing. Visited me every Saturday till I was dry. And once a week, for the last thirty years, I get four cases of bottled water sent to me, wherever I am in the world. Always with the same note: “Drink as many as you want on me, Danny.” Frank taps his water bottle.
Best friend I ever had your father. The man saved my life, got me stone-cold sober, and he was three sheets to the wind himself the entire time he was doing it.
I’m not seeing the point here.

The point, my boy, is that he’s always been better to others than he has been to himself. What you do with that, is up to you. My waters will keep coming no matter what. Frank tips an imaginary hat, turns back to the movers.
Alright, boys, let’s move that puppy so I can get the fuck out of New Jersey. Tom stands at the door, watching Frank go.

Tom holds Hope on his lap as she BANGS away on the piano (which is wildly out of place and oversized for the cramped living room). He picks Hope up, places her on the bench by herself, and kisses her forehead. Sam watches adoringly (and WILDLY pregnant) from the couch (where she lies). Tom moves to her. (CONTINUED)
He takes her hand, kisses it. He goes to pull away but she won't let him go. She has tears in her eyes. He nods at her: a solid, steadying look. He kisses her again, kisses her belly, then EXITS.
We’re used to watching Danny walk toward the house. This time, we watch his son walking away from it... toward the unknown.
A medical office building in NYC.
Tom makes the long trek down the building’s hallway, stops at a door, opens it, and...
ENTERS the waiting room, turning a corner only to see... Danny. Sitting there. Alone. Waiting. Tom shakes his head, SIGHS. He checks in with a NURSE.
Tom Donnelly. Here for Dr. Silverman.
Just have a seat, Mr. Donnelly. Tom sits two seats away from Danny. They sit in silence for a long beat. Finally:
Was she pissed?
No, she was thrilled. It’s been a great few weeks, thanks.
It’s no excuse but it was a horrible night for me. 98 99
100 (CONTINUED)
Yeah, well, it was a worse one for me, I assure you. Silence. Long beat.
Why isn’t she... (CONTINUED)
She can barely even move. Plus, whatever the news is, I want her to hear it from me. Not some doctor. A beat, then...
Tom, I--
Mr. Donnelly? The NURSE beckons. Tom STANDS. Danny STANDS with him. Tom SIGHS.
Tom and Danny wait, on an EXAM TABLE, side by side. Danny looks at Tom’s foot. It’s TAPPING, relentlessly. They sit there for a while like this. Finally:
If the news is bad... Tom stops, gathering himself.
Tom, c’mon--
No, listen to me. If this goes bad, Samantha, and Hope, and the baby--
Will be taken care of. You don’t need to worry about that. Tom nods. He’s starting to cry but doing the best he can to hold it back.
Okay. Good. Thank you. A beat. Tom speaks, almost to himself:
I am not ready to leave them. I am not ready. Danny puts his hand on Tom’s knee, steadying his shaky leg. Danny takes a deep breath himself. (CONTINUED )

You know... this doctor, whenever he comes in here, he either calls you Mr. Donnelly or Tom? Ever notice that? Always one or the other. When he calls you Mr. Donnelly, it’s never good news. Next thing you know he’s shooting you with something that makes you throw up, or telling you he doesn’t like your levels. I’m serious, I’ve taken notes, he literally does it every time. (then) But when he calls you Tom, it’s always good news. Like that time he liked your white cell count, remember that? He called you Tom. So that’s what we want right now. We want him to open that door, come in here, and call you “Tom.” That’s all we want. Let’s focus on that, okay? Tom nods, takes a deep breath.
Okay.
It's going to be alright, Son. Everything will be alright.
(choking up) You promise? Danny looks at his son.
Have I ever let you down before? Tom CRACKS UP through his tears. Crying now...
You’re a ridiculous man, you know that?
I’ve been told, yes. Tom considers the man sitting next to him, then, giving in to it... he puts his hand on top of his father’s. (CONTINUED)
The camera swings behind them, slowly, till it lands on their backs (facing the door). As it swings around, Danny continues talking, soothing.

Yep, he’s just gonna open that door and call you Tom. It will all be alright. Everything will be alright. We’re behind them now, father and son, touching hands in silence. And just then... The door OPENS. Their heads jolt up and we... FADE TO BLACK.
But not before we hear, over black:
Okay, Tom, so here’s where we are...

In 1971, John Lennon read an interview in a small music magazine. The subject of the interview was a twenty-one year old musician named Steve Tilston. In the interview, Tilston admitted wondering if future wealth and fame might one day hinder his ability to write powerful songs. And so... John Lennon wrote Steve Tilston a letter. In the letter, Lennon offered Tilston advice and friendship, as well as his home phone number. Steve Tilston did not receive the letter until 2005. He was nearly sixty years old at the time.
